answer_html: (or easier, notice that \(\displaystyle \phi(16) = 8\) so Euler’s theorem gives the same result) Thus as the number is 1, its inverse it itself.

(or easier, notice that $\displaystyle \phi(16) = 8$ so Euler's theorem

hints_html: For the first part, use Euler’s Theorem. For the second part, simply evaluate it.
hints_latex:
For the first part, use Euler's Theorem. For the second part, simply

hints_raw: For the first part, use Euler's Theorem. For the second part, simply evaluate it.
sols_html:
Euler’s Theorem states that

\[\begin{aligned} a^{\phi(b)} &\equiv 1 \mod{b} \\ b^{\phi(a)} &\equiv 1 \mod{a}\end{aligned}\]

Translating the above, there exist integers s and t such that

\[\begin{aligned} a^{\phi(b)} -1 &= bs\\ b^{\phi(a)} -1 &= at\end{aligned}\]

Taking the products of the left hand sides of the equation and the right hand sides of the equation yields (below we have flipped the sides of the equations)

\[\begin{aligned} abst &= (a^{\phi(b)} -1)(b^{\phi(a)} -1) = a^{\phi(b)}b^{\phi(a)} - a^{\phi(b)} - b^{\phi(a)} + 1\end{aligned}\]

As \(\displaystyle \phi(a)\) and \(\displaystyle \phi(b)\) are at least one, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} 0 &\equiv - a^{\phi(b)} - b^{\phi(a)} + 1 \mod{ab}\end{aligned}\]

and hence we get the required result. For the last part, we have

\(\displaystyle 5^{8} \equiv (5^{2})^{4} \equiv 25^{4} \equiv 9^{4} \equiv (9^{2})^{2} \equiv 81^{2} \equiv 1^{2} \equiv 1 \mod{16}\)

(or easier, notice that \(\displaystyle \phi(16) = 8\) so Euler’s theorem gives the same result) Thus as the number is 1, its inverse it itself.
statement_html: Show that if a and b are relatively prime integers, then \(\displaystyle a^{\phi(b)}+ b^{\phi(a)} \equiv 1 \mod{ab}\) . What is the multiplicative inverse of \(\displaystyle 5^8\) modulo 16?
statement_latex:
Show that if \emph{a} and \emph{b} are relatively prime integers, then
$\displaystyle a^{\phi(b)}+ b^{\phi(a)} \equiv 1 \mod{ab}$ . What is the
multiplicative inverse of $\displaystyle 5^8$ modulo 16?
statement_raw: Show that if ''a'' and ''b'' are relatively prime integers, then <math> \displaystyle a^{\phi(b)}+ b^{\phi(a)} \equiv 1 \mod{ab} </math> . What is the multiplicative inverse of <math> \displaystyle 5^8</math> modulo 16?
